attributes.title: Toys 'R' Us Announces Store Closures - Here's The List
summary: Toys "R" Us listed 175 stores it's seeking to close, nearly 20% of its U.S. stores.
Toy makers Hasbro, Mattel, JAKKS and more could see reduced revenue.
Toys "R" Us has been in bankruptcy since September.

attributes.content:
Bankrupt Toys “R” Us Inc. is planning to close 175 of its U.S. stores, listed at the end of this article, according to a court filing on Tuesday. That’s nearly 20% of the 881 domestic stores the company reported were operating as of October.

Update: 01/24/2018: The liquidation sales are expected to begin on February 7 and run no later than April 15. The sales are being conducted by Tiger Capital Group, B. Riley Financial Inc.’s Great American Group (NASDAQ:RILY), Hilco Merchant Resources, and Gordon Brothers Retail Partners.

Of the closures, 94 are at Babies “R” Us locations, 47 are at Toys “R” Us, and 32 properties combine both formats. Two outlet stores are also closing.

A declining U.S. birth rate has been weighing on many industries, particularly those dealing directly with infants and children.

The Wayne, N.J.-based retailer surprised the industry by filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on September 19, ahead of the holiday selling season, an especially critical time for toy stores.

Toys “R” Us had been laboring under $400 million a year in interest payments ever since a 2005 leveraged buyout by Bain Capital, KKR & Co. (NYSE:KKR), and Vornado Realty Trust (NYSE:VNO) that was valued at $7.5 billion.

Liquidity concerns came to a head earlier than expected when CNBC reported on September 6 that the company had hired restructuring attorneys Kirkland & Ellis to address its debt.

That news was enough to spook toymakers into cutting crucial holiday shipments and tightening payment terms at a time when the retailer could least afford it, as the toy seller needed extra cash for everything from seasonal hiring to a holiday ad blitz.

Pushed into Chapter 11 bankruptcy, Toys “R” Us reported in a December conference call that sales had already fallen by 7% before the news and that surveys found 17% of respondents would change their shopping habits because of the bankruptcy. According to a December 18 Bloomberg report, sales had since fallen by 15% year over year.

Chief executive Dave Brandon said on the call that the experience was “pretty stressful, pretty difficult and certainly had a negative impact on the business.” Shipments were significantly interrupted, he added, especially in October.

JAKKS Pacific (NASDAQ:JAKK), which licenses Disney and DC Comics toys, among others, said in an October 26 earnings call that it slowed, then “briefly halted” shipments to Toys “R” Us, and that this was a major factor in a 13% year-over-year drop in sales for the company. JAKKS said it expects its $1.2 million profit in 2016 to swing into a loss. The company added that shipments were still “moving a bit slower than expected” at the time of the call.

Mattel Inc. (NASDAQ:MAT) said it “made the difficult decision to begin to reduce shipments” to the retailer, and that it “took quite some time” to restore its shipping volume. Mattel’s revenues fell 8% year over year in the quarter ending September 30.

Hasbro Inc. (NASDAQ:HAS) said it “paused shipments for a short period” to Toys “R” Us, negatively affecting revenues and operating profit, though its revenue was still up 7% year over year in the three months through October 1.

In its bankruptcy petition, Toys “R” Us said it owed unpaid invoices of $136 million to Mattel, $59 million each to Hasbro and Graco (NASDAQ:NWL), $33 million to Spin Master Corp, and $14 million to JAKKS, among others.

The retailer’s top unsecured creditor was Bank of New York Mellon Corp. (NYSE:BK), to which Toys “R” Us owed at least $230 million.

Judge Keith Phillips approved $21 million in bonuses for Toys "R" Us executives, garnering public criticism. The U.S. trustee assigned to the case, Judy A. Robbins, said the idea of big bonuses for a bankrupt company “defies logic and wisdom.”

And Kirkland & Ellis’ exceptionally steep rate of up to $1,745 an hour became a poster case for a bipartisan Senate effort to end the practice of bankruptcy venue shopping. The court in Richmond, Va., where Toys “R” Us filed, has a reputation for being particularly obliging of high attorney's fees.

Several retailers went bankrupt during the normally quiet period before the end of the year. In addition to Toys “R” Us, the bankruptcies included accessories seller Charming Charlie, as well as Styles for Less, Fashion to Figure, Shiekh Shoes, Sports Zone, and women's lifestyle retailer Calypso St. Barth.

The early days of the new year have also seen the bankruptcies of Parker School Uniforms, women’s apparel store A’GACI, and the U.S. arm of cosmetics seller KIKO Milano.

Outside of bankruptcy, Sears (SHLD), Kmart, Sam’s Club (NYSE:WMT), Starbucks’ Teavana stores (NASDAQ:SBUX), Mattress Firm, Brookstone, Hallmark, J. Crew and CeX are among the retailers that have recently announced store closings, with many more that announced closures earlier in 2017 but held off until after Christmas.

Vitamin World, already in bankruptcy, sought to close an additional 124 stores in November.

Beyond retailers, 600 hair salons by Regis Corp. (NASDAQ:RGS) are closing.

In addition, The Bon-Ton Stores Inc. (BONT), a chain of 260 department stores under seven different nameplates, is said to be near bankruptcy, while teen apparel retailer Charlotte Russe has engaged in an out-of-court restructuring.

The house of Geoffrey the Giraffe isn’t just closing U.S. stores, it’s currently shutting down 25 stores in the United Kingdom.

Here’s the list of Toys “R” Us (TRU), Babies “R” Us (BRU), side-by-side combined Toys "R" Us and Babies "R" Us (SBS), and outlet stores that are closing in the U.S.:

Editor's Note: This article covers one or more microcap stocks. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.
